user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Initialize:
```c
void OS_BSP_Initialize(void)
{
    FILE *              fp;
    char                buffer[32];
    pthread_mutexattr_t mutex_attr;
    int                 status;

    /*
     * If not running as root, check /proc/sys/fs/mqueue/msg_max
     *
     * This special file represents the max depth of a POSIX message queue for an unprivileged user.
     *
     * In order to facilitate running in simulation mode without any need for root access --
     * this will allow the OSAL to successfully create message queues by truncating anything larger than this size.
     *
     * No need to check _LINUX_OS_ here; if the file fails to open, i.e. if not on Linux and the file does not exist,
     * then leave well enough alone and don't do anything.
     */
    if (geteuid() != 0)
    {
        fp = fopen("/proc/sys/fs/mqueue/msg_max", "r");
        if (fp)
        {
            if (fgets(buffer, sizeof(buffer), fp) != NULL)
            {
                OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth = OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(strtoul(buffer, NULL, 10));
                BSP_DEBUG("Maximum user msg queue depth = %u\n", (unsigned int)OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth);
            }
            fclose(fp);
        }
    }

    /* Initialize the low level access mutex (w/priority inheritance) */
    status = pthread_mutexattr_init(&mutex_attr);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutexattr_init: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    status = pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_PRIO_INHERIT);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    status = pthread_mutex_init(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex, &mutex_attr);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_init: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_Initialize:
#define OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(X) ((osal_blockcount_t)(X))
...
extern OS_BSP_GlobalData_t OS_BSP_Global
...
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Only the three if-blocks shown above were flagged for investigation. All other code in OS_BSP_Initialize is either plainly reachable or conditional on runtime state and therefore does not indicate statically unreachable code:

- The initial geteuid() check and the nested fopen/fgets/strtoul sequence are runtime-dependent (may or may not execute depending on the effective UID and file presence) and so are not statically unreachable.
- The variable declarations, buffer usage, and assignments (including the calls that set status) are executed sequentially and are reachable at runtime.
- The BSP_DEBUG macro is defined as an empty macro in the provided additional code; its invocations compile away to no-ops but do not introduce other unreachable code fragments beyond the ones already listed.
- There are no other unconditional return/goto/loop constructs or dead labels that would produce additional unreachable code in the shown function.

Therefore, no other fragments need investigation for Rule 2.1 based on the provided code.
